Chris Turner wrote:

>--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "logical_creations" <chris@l...> wrote:
>  
>
>
>I managed to solve the problem.  I made the assumption that as the 
>output signal is between 0 and 1, that the input signals should also 
>be beween 0 and 1.  This is why I divided the number by 10 when 
>setting the value.
>
>After removing the divide by 10, the network learned to reach 100 
>fitness which is what I wanted to achieve.  The only thing still 
>puzzling me is that I'm not sure that I understand why there is a 
>different between dividing the input signal by 10 and not dividing.
>  
>
Hi Chris,

As you probably noticed most of the SharpNEAT experiments scale inputs 
to the 0..1 range as you did, although I generally consider this to be 
not /that/ important. The reason being that the input signals get scaled 
by the connections feeding the signals into the network proper (input 
nodes don't apply an activation function). By default SharpNEAT has a 
connection weight range of -5.0 to 5.0, thus scaling by up to 5x is 
possible and scaling down is also possible with weigths <1.0. Note that 
the +-5.0 range roughly ties in with the activation functions available, 
they generally give a minimum output(of zero) for inputs of <=-5.0 and a 
max output(of 1.0) for >=5.0.

It's not immediately clear to me why your experiment should succeed by 
using input signals over the range 1..9, I would guess that by not 
scaling the inputs down that the input signals are more likely to 
generate values at the far ends of the activation function, thus pretty 
much reducing the function to a step function - which might be a more 
appropriate function for the sequence problem.

Another important point is that the version you have contains a couple 
of significant bugs that will be hindering sharpneats ability to find a 
solution. I'll send you a link to the current code base just in case you 
wish to switch over to that - if anyone else is interested in this then 
let me know.  I'll try and get round to a new release some day soon, honest!

Colin.
